field_edited_text.value:
A MESSAGE FROM MAYOR WILLIAM DONALD SCHAEFER

Great opportunity awaits you in Market Center downtown. Here
in the heart of Baltimore, we have turned plans into successful results
which will generate a good return on your future investments. The
Charles Center complex and our Inner Harbor are internationally
acclaimed proof that the Baltimore development process works.

Our newest venture, Market Center, is a continuation of our other
important development successes. Handsome buildings, many quali-
fying for tax credits, are available for retail, residential, and commer-
cial rehabilitation. Prime sites for new single use and mixed-use
development are available throughout the District. Currently, close
to $250 million in public/private construction is underway or com-
pleted with much more coming on stream this year.

We have worked very hard in Baltimore to make it easy for business
people to achieve their development goals. The City has poured
millions of dollars into needed public improvements and necessary
public financing for projects. A vital ingredient in the Market Center
development mix has been the active participation of a Project Area

Committee whose 800 members have critiqued and endorsed the
planning process. Among the more unique approaches are a promo-
tion fee used to advertise retail and special events and an upgrading
of 650 area facades, perhaps the most ambitious such undertaking
in the nation.

Market Center’s success is the result of a combination of impor-
tant elements: a positive partnership between all levels of government,
a vibrant private sector involvement, and the support and good will
of the Market Center business people, the media, and principally,
the citizens of Baltimore. It is a stunning example of a progressive
vision in urban development producing opportunities and results!

I cordially urge you to visit us and discover these unique oppor-
tunities for your future growth.

Sinc

THE CROSSROADS OF BALTIMORE

The Crossroads at Howard and Lexington Streets has long
been the heart of Baltimore. Within two blocks of this vital
location, over 2,000 new employees now work in more than
600,000 square feet of new and rehabilitated office/retail
space.

The Crossroads is the center of downtown transportation
modes. The new Howard Street Transit Mall intersects with
Lexington Mall, the busiest pedestrian corridor downtown.
This tree-lined, brick promenade links the Charles Center
office cluster with the world-famous Lexington Market.
Along the way are three department stores and scores of
specialty shops.

As the name implies, The Crossroads is the focus of
downtown activity. Within a few minutes’ walk are various

office, residential and recreational options, as well as approx-
imately one million square feet of retail space. Many of
Baltimore’s world-class cultural and educational institutions
are no more than a 10 to 15 minute walk away. Many of
Baltimore’s famous restaurants and hotels are within an easy

walk of The Crossroads.

The major station stop on the Baltimore Metro, less than
a block away, runs ahead of ridership projections. Some
three-fourths of all Metro buses stop on or just off Howard
Street. Over 4,000 off-street spaces are within a two-minute
walk. Super highway access is just down the street, providing
an easy drive time to Washington, DC.



M EISENHOWER LIBRARY |
